I got the PlayStation 5 on Launch Day in November 2020. The quality of the games and their performance has really improved and been maximized! Going into this new generation has really opened my eyes to how gaming can keep improving. I had initially thought that there was no way for game visuals and scope to improve and get better beyond the PS4 generation.When trying out remasters of the last-generation games, you will immediately notice that nearly every game has a 60FPS (Frames Per Second) Mode. When swinging around in Spiderman or brawling in God of War, the performance really makes the games feel fresh and so much better. They not only look better but also feel and move better. It is like you're playing on a Beast-Computer. You will notice that the games are not really making as many compromises in their overall scope and vision.The DualSense Controller has been one of the most innovative factors for me personally. Game controllers have had vibration and haptic feedback rumble before this console, but this new controller really changes the games. You actually feel moments and elements that were originally meant to only be visual through the game. When driving a car in Gran Turismo 7, you feel the weight of the car in the controller. You feel the the road at the bottom half of the controller and whether it is rainy or not will impact that feel. In a Military Action Video Game, you feel each weapon differently and can even feel spinning helicopter blades within the controller moving! A game involving Archery will have a certain expected tension in the triggers like a real-life bow/arrow. The Dualsense controller connects you to the game and really feels next-generation. You have the option to turn off the haptics but it is very cool!Going back to the performance of the new console, it really is super-fast! It comes with an impressive Solid State Drive for storing your games internally and loading a game literally takes one or two seconds. Waiting for a few minutes is a thing of the past! The UI and overall experience really feels new and works fast and great. Some have been skeptical about this next-generation but this is one where not only the visuals of games improve but also their actual realistic feel in your hands.The PlayStation 5 is fun! The Lineup is really amazing and everything looks and plays in a great standard of quality.

I have been a loyal Playstation fan from day 1. I preordered this before release date. I am going through an issue that causes the PS5 to overheat and power itself off mid-game. I sent my PS5 back to Sony 2 times already, and just sent another repair request. They said they will send me a box to return for repair on 08/26/22 and today is 09/28/22, still have not received the box. They do not seem to care about the issue as this would be my 3rd time returning the system. I am extremely unhappy. I work 60 hours a week and with only 1 off day, I do not want to waste my time waiting on the phone for hours to complain. I have a life.  This overheating issue seems to happen when I play a specific game. Whenever I play No Man's Sky for 2+ hours it overheats and powers off. Then the power button does not work. To get the PS5 to work again I have to unplug the power cord and plug it back in. Only then it will power on again. But once this starts happening, it keeps decreasing the time I can keep the PS5 on before it powers off again.  I would try to buy another one, but the PS5 is still not openly available. This is not right!

I purchased my PS5 console over a year ago not too long after they came out. First I will say that getting one was not easy at that time, but I was very happy with it when I bought it. I upgraded from a PS4 Pro.  This console is much faster ableit larger and more obvious in the room.  I love playing games on this machine and am an avid gamer.  Since the console only comes with one controller I purchased a second. Well that arrived and didn't work right.  Kept racing up and down the tabs, you could not use it, so back it went. Then I ordered another which worked well at first. But it just recently died, same issue? So I ordered yet another at $74.00. + tax. Guess what same issue when I connected it? So I then returned it and finally got a replacement that works. To me this is just not acceptable quality control on Sony's part given the outlandish  price they are charging for the consoles aa well as the controllers. I think they put too much technical effort into the controllers without making them more sturdy. I don't abuse my equipment, but occasionally the controller will fall to the floor from the arm of my chair etc.  It can't handle being dropped at all.  And clearly given that I have received a number of them with problems, they cannot even handle ruff handling in retail warehouse. To me at nearly $100.00 the controller are the real failure of this system.  Also, I might add that the square button on the latest controller is a bit wonky.  Sometimes I have to press it so hard to get it to engage it makes my fingers hurt.  This makes gaming hard when you are in the middle of a battle etc. So I find myself sometimes going back to my PS4 Pro which is a workhorse and very reliable.  I have four controllers for that and all still work as new.  Sony for the price you are charging make a better product.  The controllers are junk and overpriced. Also they are heavy as hell.  Not what I have come to expect from Sony after years of buying nothing but Sony.  All my video electronics are Sony. I have owned four Sony TV's over the past 30 years.  Not a of them every died or had a problem. I only upgraded to larger sets or flat panels as technology changed.  So to me this console set as a whole falls short of the mark on what I have come to expect from Sony.  Please make or improve your controllers. And offer a better warranty as well. You are charging too much for this kind of issues right out of the box.

To be perfectly clear. I would normally give this 5 stars... but since you can't get one over a year after launch unless you pay a scalper or reseller twice what it's worth I can't recommend getting one until Sony puts out more units for sale, which is unlikely due to the global chip shortage. And no, you shouldn't have to sign up for special opportunities through major retailers to get a chance at buying one before everyone else. Not a year after launch when early adopters should already have one and the general public should have access to new units. After the supply shortage gets figured out and units are readily available without having to spend twice what they're worth, I'll change my rating.As far as games go, Sony has arguably the best first party lineup currently, with God of War, Horizon, Ghost of Tsushima, Gran Turismo, The Last of Us, Uncharted, Demon's Souls, etc. just to name a few. First party games look spectacular, and since it's backwards compatible with PS4, with a lot of major games getting next-gen upgrades you really can't be spoiled enough for choice of games. The console also has a fantastic 4K blu-ray player.The controller is very comfortable, though with some questionable features. I don't like the microphone being built into the controller. Sure it's a decent alternative if you don't want to wear a headset, but too many people in online games forget to mute it, thinking they've muted themselves on their headset and it can get annoying. I'm not a fan of the reactive triggers. Let's say you're playing a game where you use a bow and arrow; the reactive triggers will increase tension in the trigger as you pull the bowstring in-game, so it makes it more difficult to keep the bow drawn for extended periods of time. This can be great for immersion, but personally I just find it makes my fingers sore. Thankfully this can be turned off.

Managed to snag this beast off Amazon randomly during one of the few times they‚Äôve had them. No clue how other than refreshing a lot. I feel bad for those of you who‚Äôve yet to grab one, but while it‚Äôs a great console, it‚Äôs not *that* amazing. Needs more ps5 exclusive games before I‚Äôd worry too much. I still play my PS4 in the bedroom when the boy takes over the living room tv and have a blast. So, don‚Äôt let the urge to get your hands on one overwhelm you. You‚Äôll get yours!I do love the console, though. I use it and my series x (again, got super lucky again, but on wally morts website that time) about the same amount.The ps5 is indistinguishable verses the series X in terms of power that I‚Äôve seen. They‚Äôre both powerful consoles and outshine my aging 1070ti pc by a ton (that‚Äôs been the hardest to upgrade for me).The UI is a fresh look and functional enough. I like the store is just there to select when you feel and it doesn‚Äôt have to ‚Äúload‚Äù the store like on ps4 and ps3. I like that it has a pull up *task* bar, for lack of better words, that you can quickly pull up and make on the fly adjustments to the sound control, accounts, etc.The best upgrade are the new controllers, imo. Haptic feedback is a neat feature, though honestly not a deal breaker if games don‚Äôt utilize it. It‚Äôs cool to feel different guns in games have different trigger feel/pull. My favorite part is the size and shape redesign. Fits my semi larger hands much better, but my 11 year old has no issues, either. It just feels better, if you know what I mean. The one downside I‚Äôve found here is battery life. Absolutely a downgrade verses the PS4 controllers.The ssd is fast and does a good job. The only downside, and it‚Äôs kinda big, is the super specific drive you have to buy if you want to upgrade the internal drive. They‚Äôre crazy expensive, much like the series X, but more so. Who knows how long we have to wait to see larger than 1TB affordable drives that will work.The console itself is a chonker, so make sure you have the space for ventilation. Not a huge fan of the design, but you can see the design and make your own decision.Good luck on your hunt and keep trying. If you refuse to pay scalpers, as I did, get on Twitter and follow a few of the accounts that alert you to upcoming ps5 stock. That‚Äôs how I heard about the Amazon stock when I got this one.Also, screw scalpers. That is all.

Yes, it‚Äôs just impossible to buy a PS5, but also any nVidia RTX cards because of the GPU shortage and the scalpers looking to make a quick buck. Actually I‚Äôve seen manufacturers adding a fan or two and selling the same card with 70% more profit! This uncharted territory can only be solved by Sony and other manufacturers releasing new products every other year. People judge Apple for incremental updates, but that model has worked very well. It would be less likely to see any shortage one year into the release if another one is coming, because it would be less entertaining for scalpers to invest their money on items that are going to be obsolete soon. If you can get your hands on this, it is 100% worth the price.The controller is awesome and it always surprises me how each dualshock generation blows away the last gen. The haptic feedback on the triggers is worth the hype, I just hope they will release more games that utilize this tech in the future.But really, backwards compatibility is why I bought this. I typically only buy a console after it's been out a few years because of the small game selection at launch and I'm not willing to pay $70 for a new game. Those criticisms are out the window this gen because my entire ps4 library is now my ps5 library. Even better, some games have had free ps5 upgrades (No Man's Sky) that really boost the graphics and add haptic feedback support. And games without a ps5 upgrade will generally run at a solid 60fps and have lightning fast load times.Do what I did, buy this and sell your old ps4 to help pay for it. I sold my ps4 pro for $300, so this console upgrade only really cost me $200. For 200 bucks, this is a no brainer (if, and this is a big IF, you can find it at MSRP).

They charged over over $ 1000.00 for this PlayStation 5 and they couldn‚Äôt even make it right. I could see if a couple of months had gone by and I asked for help after that long but it was 38 days. They swear it was brand new but it wasn‚Äôt. They wouldn‚Äôt even offer an exchange or anything. We finally got one from a legitimate retailer and believe me it‚Äôs still working right and we are so happy and excited. We even tried to get it fixed and the place we took it to said the  motor was burnt out and that the problem was  definitely internal. They said this shouldn‚Äôt have happened if it was brand new like this seller said. Please keep your money. Don‚Äôt buy from this seller. If they even tried to offer a refund or exchange I would‚Äôve acknowledged that they at least tried to help us out. The holidays are coming and some of these sellers will be trying to push off old refurbished products  and old used items. It‚Äôs up to us to call them out on it especially if they claim what they are selling is brand new. It‚Äôs up to us to let others know in an in depth review about things that aren‚Äôt right! DON‚ÄôT FALL FOR IT! Go to the more legitimate retailers. In this case I didn‚Äôt even pay for the new one what I paid for this one. I told the new retailer I went to what happened and they actually gave me a discount. The one we got was a real legitimate brand new Play Station 5 with a warranty of 2 years yes 2 years is what they gave me, they also knocked some off of the price they were selling it for in the store. So in some ways we still came out on top but I wanted to let somebody know who might stumble across this seller and think you might be getting a legitimate deal. YOU‚ÄôRE NOT! Some sellers just take more pride in making their customers happy this one DID‚ÄôNT. I have never even heard of this seller but I tried to give them the benefit of the doubt . I am not writing this review to be bitter. I‚Äôm writing it because it‚Äôs the Truth!  They didn‚Äôt hesitate to brush me off. I wanted anyone who was thinking about buying from them to think long and hard about it. We even tried to call Sony because this seller said well  call the manufacturer that‚Äôs basically all we can tell you to do. We tried Sony and they said well you can ship it to us but it will probably be after the holidays  or maybe longer into the next year before we can even look at it. Please don‚Äôt try and delete my review. People need to know about these products you guys are trying to push off on unsuspecting buyers!

For me, the PS 5 is a very good machine.  I is my main non-PC gaming console at this time... but it was a bit of a luxury, as my PS4 still works great.  Due to what cons there are, I really recommend waiting for the M2 drive slot to become officially unlocked with an affordable M2 drive to be able to be purchases to expand the internal storage memory to be sufficiently expanded AND to be able to purchase the console at its MSRP price (or lower).If you absolutely don't or can't wait,  I only recommend purchasing the PS5 if 1) Your PS4 has died, 2) There are specific PS5 titles you want to play now and just can't wait, 3) You have money to spare totally on a luxury.PROS:Fast, excellent performance.Excellent, HD graphics.Comfortable controllers.Compatible with the PlayStation VR headset with the free adapter you can order from Sony PlayStation.I am able to play my entire PS4 library. 100+ games so far without issues.PS5 titles that are releasing look awesome. I so far have only 1 PS5 title, but it plays great and I love it.All the popular streaming services are available for the PS5: Amazon Prime, Netflix, Hulu, Disney, etc.Can use up to a 8 TB external drive for all your PS4 titles to make room for PS5 titles on the internal storage memory. (Note: You can only use 1 external drive at a time, but you can swap them by properly stopping the current drive before unplugging it and plugging in the new one)All 4 USB ports are high speed USB 3.1 ports with one of them being a type C port, Ideal for an external SSD for storage expansion and playing your PS4 games.Has a M2 SSD slot for M2 SSD hard drives to increase the internal storage, once Sony releases the unlock on the slot (BUT see the cons for the exception to this point).Comes with the stand instead of having to buy one separately, and it is used both for horizontal and vertical positions.Both the top and bottom panel covers are not only easily removable for component installation/replacement/repair, the covers can be easily replaced with 3rd party covers, so you can change the color of your panels.CONS:BIGGEST CON - It only has about 667 GB of SSD onboard memory, which will be eaten up quickly by newer software titles, AND the M2 SSD internal expansion slot is locked and unusable at this time, as Sony wants to be sure of the models and configurations of the M2 drives are 100% compatible with the console and it's current capability to dissipate the heat generated by the M2 SSD drives.  It's been over a year, and they still have yet to unlock the expansion slot.  Because of this con, and if you already have a PS4, I recommend holding off buying this until they unlock the M2 slot, or unless your PS4 dies and are looking for a replacement.  I have bought an 8TB external SSD for my PS5 to play all my PS4 games from, but it literally added $650 to my overall cost of my PS5.The console housing is allot thicker that it's predecessor consoles by almost double in thickness, so plan accordingly.Has a total of only 4 USB slots:  2 rear USB 3, 1 front USB 3, and 1 front USB type C.  The problem with this is if you have the PlayStation VR, a external SSD for PS4 games and PS5 storage, and utilize a charging cable for the controller, all ports will be taken up.You can use only 1 external drive at a time, making it awkward to transfer files and vids to your dive for viewing on your PS5, or increasing your storage further past the external 8TB.They removed the web browser and only have a limited, lockdown browser that is meant only to be used with their online PS5 guides and tech support manuals and forums.  Youtube, Twitch, and many other streaming media platforms are still available through their individual media apps on PS5.Only comes in white with black trim, and all the accessories (except the controllers) are also only available in white with black trim.

The new Call of Duty alone is about 200¬†GB making it 1/4 of all the storage on the console, add another 100 for the system software and its almost 1/2 of all the storage you have taken by a single game. Everything else is perfect and easy to set up and use.

Well, it is a PS-5, so of course it is a good product--IF, AND ONLY IF, you can get one w/o paying some scalper twice the price on ebay.  I just object to that.  Amazon (And other retailers) did not seem to attempt to help you, but Sony is trying.  If you register for an account with them, or if you have one, go update some items, and add say a PS5 controller or other PS5 accessory to your cart, you will likely get an email inviting you to buy one during a two hour window.  This works--at least for me, and some other folks I spoke with.  Sony seems to do this every couple of weeks.  1. Follow their instructions.  2.  Before the window opens, have a browser (The default one that email links open on your device.) open and be already logged into Playstation.  3. Click on the link around one second after the clock hits the start of the window.  4. Add the PS5 to your cart.  5. Hit checkout, and enter credit card info.  [Site did not pick up on my card already stored in the site.]  6. Hit purchase (After the review step.)  7.  Hit it again.  8. Be patient--it may take a few minutes.  9. Want to be a hero Dad?  Do this NOW.  If you wait until end of September, or later, the Christmas rush will be on and this will not get easier.  Good Luck.For the Amazon folks attempting to battle the scalpers and scalper bots--you need to do better.

Thankfully my phone charger is the USB type C cord, which is NOT included and absolutely necessary to even begin to use a PS5. (At least my daughters toys are labeled on the outside of the package that batteries are not included)My ps4 pro has more saved game data than the ps5 has storage for. The ps5 system has a funky bulky retro feel that takes up more counter space than the slimmer ps4 pro.I purchased this bundle at over 2x retail with NO extra games,  headset or controllers because it had the fastest delivery date in comparison to much better valued bundles, however the shipping was "unforeseeably delayed" and arrived at the same estimated arrival date as better valued bundles were quoting.If you have a ps4 account already, you will want to plug the ps5 in side by side to transfer data, or be stuck on a data transfer screen until you do.Update 2wks later::We've been running the PS5 and 2 PS4 Pros via same type of ethernets side by side in COD Cold War, Warzone, and Modern Warfare for 2 weeks. Here is our family's results.Ps5-dowloads the games faster and loads into game lobbies faster, the few titles it can hold at a time at least.Ps4 Pro- same shooting speed as ps5 (if not possibly advantageous lag in competitive shooter games) and more storage for another big game.Overall we have decided we will not be ordering any more PS5s until a pro version is released, or the price drops dramatically. It's not worth even the retail price for our use.

I've had the PS5 for almost 8 months now and i am very pleased. This device is such a refreshing upgrade from the previous generation. As someone who has bought every PlayStation since the PS2, I have to say that overall, the experience overall is very good. All the things that took a bunch of time before, whether it‚Äôs regarding system tasks, or in-game screens, now happen in a flash. However, there are 3 main areas where they took a step back in my opinion, and 1 of them is why they only get 1 star from me:1) Messages and Party Chats used to be way more user friendly on my PS4 Pro. After a couple months of use it‚Äôs still so clunky to use because you can‚Äôt just start a party independently you have to start up a message group first, even if it‚Äôs with people you barely know, and then send an invite to the chat to the group. It‚Äôs a huge step backwards to me because it‚Äôs slow and now you have to leave all the message groups after each party you create or they pile up and bury your real message groups.2) The hard drive space. They took about a third of the usable hard drive space away from last generation and you feel it. I never needed an external hard drive, and it‚Äôs cool that it‚Äôs a feature to be able to use one, but for a $500 device to almost require an outside device for a basic functionality is in poor taste. I say almost because I have 5 games installed and I‚Äôm at full capacity. You may only play 1 or 2 games at once and just delete them so this won‚Äôt be an issue. For me, I like to have more choice readily available, and on my PS4 Pro I swear I had north of 10 games installed at once for whatever mood I was in. This isn‚Äôt a deal breaker but it is a minor/major inconvenience depending on who you are.3) This is the big one‚Ä¶ I haven‚Äôt had the system long at all. It only just came out November of 2020 so no one has, but already, the controller is malfunctioning. It‚Äôs referred to as ‚Äúdrift‚Äù, where your character you controller will just move on their own without you moving the analog stick because of an issue with the analog stick. I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve never experienced this before with other systems, but not only was it rare, but when it occurred, it took years and years of playing before it happened. This system recently released and I‚Äôve been busy so I haven‚Äôt played it much until recently now that it‚Äôs summer, and already I‚Äôm experiencing drift, and not minor drift like some old controllers, but major, makes the controller unusable even in the menus drift. The system is $500, the controller alone is $70, and you can‚Äôt use PS4 controllers with the system. All of these facts make it absolutely unacceptable that the controller would cease to operate correctly in such a short span of time. This is supposed to be premium tech, ‚Äúnext gen‚Äù, so the equipment should operate accordingly. The fact I‚Äôm now backed into a corner where I have to decide if I have to spend another $70 after a couple of months to replace the controller is a disgrace, and is the primary reason for my 1 star rating because the whole system is useless without faulty tech they included.

It‚Äôs a bit too early to say that you should just buy it, but as far as can see, it‚Äôs worth the money. Graphics aren‚Äôt too different just yet and most games are still coming for PS4, however, that‚Äôs not the reason to buy a PS5 right now, the reason is to get that fluid 60fps experience with Playstation exclusives and next gen games with PS4 games getting upgrades to PS5 or already having uncapped FPS so they already can go to 60fps with no updates, also to get the near instant or no loading at all in newer games. Compared to my PS4 base, it‚Äôs dead quiet, I actually managed to forget that a game was running due to it not being a jet engine to tell me. One disadvantage would be storage, there‚Äôs simple bare minimum, if you install full Warzone and Black Ops, you already just have a quarter of the space for other games, not everyone have all components of those games at the same time, but I‚Äôm mentioning it just to get a sense of how small the storage is. After almost a year after buying the ps5 for retail price (500 disc version) it's been great. The fan isn't near as loud as the ps4, it's still noticeable but nowhere near as the ps4. If you have headphones you'd wouldn't be able to notice. The ps5 does deliver on the upgraded load time. The controller alone is amazing with the rumble and adaptive triggers. There are some games that uses the controller to its full extent such as Astros playroom game, and the new rachet and clank. You can feel every foot step you take. Not to mention the power of the guns in rainbow six and other fps games. It's been a really great product, I just wish the whole launch would've gone better. Everyone online was suggesting a queue system and allowing only people to buy once. It could've gone alone smoother. Ps5 itself I've had no problems with at all despite a lot of people online saying things about the rest mode an etc which since then has been fixed. I give it 5/5 however launch a 1/5 stars.

Proud owner of a the next gen console, PlayStation 5. I wished it was more available to purchase than sold out. I had great luck to order the ps5 when it came instock online. It is a heavy console weighing at around 9 lbs or 4.45 kg. It is the tallest console in vertical position compare to the xbox series x. I am please with how the console looks and especially the newer redesigned dualsense controller. I find out that it also has a M.2 expansion slot to further allow more ssd storage for the PlayStation 5, which will come in a further update this coming summer. Safe to say, i am liking the new features and details on the PS5. With the new uhd blu-ray disc drive finally in this next gen console, makes it even better for the price, and also further your use of the next gen console. In my opinion it looks much better in the vertical position, some like it in horizontal position. Performance wise is pretty fast, not sure how Sony did it, but they did. This is a great next gen console and can't wait for great games to come.  Overall, it arrived safe, i have yet to play any games on it. But i am liking the new design and will have it stand next to my 4k hdr tv. This is a great console and sony took it to the next level in terms of design and power.

I purchased this console at launch, and was lucky enough to get the Series X shortly after it launched. The PS5 is a fantastic piece of hardware; however, it has almost been a year and Sony still doesn't offer an internal storage solution. Microsoft offers storage, albeit at a premium, so it's absurd that Sony struggles to figure out what hard drives are compatible and provide a list to consumers. Less than 1TB of storage is completely unacceptable when 60-100GB games is the norm. I love the system, but I'm only using it to play Sony exclusives from here on. When a title is available for both consoles, I purchase it for X Box.

Yes, it‚Äôs difficult to get. I‚Äôm here to encourage you. Don‚Äôt give in to scalpers. Just keep trying. Your day will come. Seriously. You‚Äôll be so happy with yourself if you stick with it and persevere for retail price.With that out of the way, the system is amazing. Just not having load times for PS4 games is worth it for me. One thing I don‚Äôt like is that it‚Äôs so big. Takes up way too much room.  Also, new UI is trash. Not intuitive at all. I‚Äôm constantly Googling how to do simple stuff since it‚Äôs not obvious. Just looking at trophies is a pain.
It‚Äôs wonderful! Great graphics and some PS4 games updated to 60 FPS!
Hard to get but definitely worth it. While most of the games I‚Äôm playing were on the PS4 and just updated, they really do look amazing and play much smoother on the PS5

A lot of games support 4k 60 fps which is excellent and the quality of the PS5 in general is great. Look premium, feels premium, the controller feels absolutely fantastic to the point that its my favorite controller, the UI isn't an ugly mess like the PS4 one. My problems with it so far is voice chat ONLY comes out of the controller if there's no headset plugged in with no way to change it. I don't know why this decision was made but oh well. For those with a high end set up, the console doesn't support HDR10+ (tho it seems like nothing ever will either), Dolby Vision or Dolby Atmos. Another problem is optical cable output, it doesn't support it. What's worse is if you connect it thru your TV, there WILL be audio lag. So if you're using a soundbar/sound system, be prepared to switch to ARC HDMI, AV Output or buy a converter for optical to ARC. Oh and the final big thing is storage size. it's about 600 gigs, completely unacceptable in these days when most games hit over 50 gigs. If you're a Warzone player, have fun with 150 gigs, 200 gigs if you want the 4K texture packs. You can use an external HDD/SSD but PS5 games will NOT work them. PS5 DOES have a PCIe slot for the new age storage, I don't have one but I know that there's no support for it yet.

The PlayStation 5 is absolutely SUPERB in ALL aspects of gaming. it is a Worthy successor to the phenomenal PS4/PS4 pro console in EVERY single way! the first thing you will notice right off the bat is how FAST the console is, from the user interface to playing games waiting is a thing of the past! the PS5 is the fastest games console I've EVER experienced, it even outperforms my buddies PC setup with his SSD which REALLY took me by surprise! The biggest downfall to the PS5 is the storage situation, with 825GB SSD (only 667GB is usable) Modern Warfare & Warzone alone account for almost 200GB. As of April 2021 you can now store & play ALL PS4 games from an external drive which is awesome! you can now store PS5 games on the external drive as well but you can NOT play PS5 games that are stored in the external drive you would have to transfer it back to the PS5 SSD in order to play PS5 games. Speaking of games, the PS5 doesn't disappoint when it comes to games! let me start by saying every PS4 games I've played loads faster & performs BETTER than the PS4 pro did. When it comes to PS5 games they're simply amazing! The Dual Sense controller is the MOST innovative feature rich controller I've EVER used! the haptics are brilliantly implemented & the adaptive triggers make games feel like every squeeze of the trigger matters. My PS5 games library consists of Astro's Playroom (the BEST pack in game since Wii sports) Black ops cold war, Mile Morales, Fortnite, Rogue Company & Genshin impact. Astro's Playroom is a fantastic platform that acts as a showcase for the new Dual Sense controller providing a fun game that shows exactly how amazing the controller truly is! Black ops cold war is decent, the load times are great but it's not next level when it comes to gameplay. Miles Morales on the other hand is next level, it's absolutely gorgeous running at 4K 60fps! it offers superb gameplay that's breathtaking showing a glimpse of what's possible on PS5! Fortnite is another game that's REALLY blown me away with it's PS5 upgrade! the game not ONLY loads so much faster compared to PS4 pro but it looks phenomenal in 4K at 60fps plus it's got improved textures & lighting & it's insane how much BETTER it is compared to the PS4 pro version! Rogue Company recently released their PS5 upgrade & it runs at a native 4K 60fps making for another beautiful free to play shooter on the PS5. Genshin impact is another amazing game that has gotten even BETTER with it's PS5 upgrade. load times are almost non existent & it's stunningly gorgeous!Final thoughts after 1 month: The PS5 has dethroned my PS4 pro as the BEST games console of ALL time imo! it plays my massive PS4 library with upgraded performance. It offers truly superb next level speed with it's SSD & the upgraded CPU / GPU along with 16GB of GDDR6 RAM make for an extremely powerful games console capable of games that we can't even fathom at the moment! I can't wait to see what the future holds for the PS5!I definitely recommend this console for anyone wanting the best playstation console ever made.PS5 tech specs:CPU: Custom 8-core AMD Zen 2,variable frequency, up to 3.5 GHzMemory: 16 GB GDDR6 SDRAM512 MB DDR4 RAM (for background tasks)Storage: Custom 825 GB SSDRemovable storageInternal (user upgradeable) NVMe M.2 SSD, or external USB-based HDDDisplay: Video output formatsHDMI: 720p, 1080i, 1080p, 4K UHD, 8K UHDGPU: Custom AMD RDNA 2,36 CUs @ variable frequency up to 2.23 GHzSound: Custom Tempest Engine 3D AudioDolby Atmos & DTS:X (Blu-Ray video & UHD Blu-Ray video) 7.1 surround soundController input: DualSense, DualShock 4, PlayStation MoveConnectivity: Wi-Fi IEEE 802.11axBluetooth 5.1Gigabit Ethernet2√ó USB 3.2 Gen 2√ó11√ó USB 2.01√ó USB-C with USB 3.2 Gen 2√ó11√ó HDMI 2.1Online services: PlayStation NetworkPlayStation Now

My oldest son really wanted the PS5, but it was nearly impossible to find anywhere until one day I hit the jackpot! I know that there hasn‚Äôt been many games out for the PS5 however the experience is worth it. The reason for this is due to the better performance of this machine. Compared to the PS4 slim, I don‚Äôt have to wait hours just to update a patch or download a game as it downloads at 600ish MBPS over ethernet on a gigbit line. The console feels fast with no pauses, stutters, and little wait time to get into a game. Any PS4 game that has weird stutters or graphic pop in no longer shows up on the PS5 due to its power performance. The PS5 controller feels great with its large size , feedback with rumble, and feedback triggers. It‚Äôs not all perfect though. There is some question when it comes to the controller as there are some people complaining about controller drift which I didn‚Äôt get as of yet. My personal issue with the controller is battery life as it only lasts under 6 hours from a full charge. This worries me as when the controller gets older, the battery life will just get worse overtime. The other issue comes to its size as it is almost the same as a mid tower desktop. The last issue which is minor is you can‚Äôt place custom backgrounds from or use purchased backgrounds from PS4 into PS5. That takes away as I use custom wallpapers to make the Playstation unique to myself. Considering all of this, I am glad that I decided to get this console not only to be able to play next gen games, but for higher quality and smooth gameplay which was often not the case when playing on a PS4 console. If only there was available stock as this was a pain to try and buy.

For this PlayStation 5 Console, I really enjoy the design of this console. It stands out and matches my theme of my room.  Upon set up, It came with the plug to function the PlayStation, a PlayStation 5 controller, PlayStation stand, and a charging cable for the controller. The package of it is clean and nice. There's 2 layers when opening the box. An outside layer showing the PlayStation 5 console and then a cardboard box shell protecting the inside. I will state my likes and dislikes for this console.Likes:- Design and Compatibility with PS4 games.- High definition quality when playing games.- 4k TV works really well with this console.- Controller feels really durable and better than the PS4.Dislikes:- A bit heavier than previous model of the PS4.- No games to really play.- I wish the packaging of the console was a bit smaller. It's too big for people to notice it.- No accessories included such as Camera or a media remote.Some suggestions, I would suggest if PlayStation wants to make their customer feel satisfied, they should provide a trial for any games from the PlayStation Store. Extra controller grips, just in case the default ones get torn apart or off.Overall, great product for a new generation console. I let my kids play it when they're finished with their homework. From time to time, I play whenever I get the chance or off work. If you only can afford a console, I'd pick this up rather than a computer.

Good:Load times have been reduced to 30 or fewer seconds. 17 seconds to load AC: Valhalla. 4k is beautiful. Games run 60fps or "Quality" mode for intense and realistic visuals at 30fps. Controller is 10/10 with haptic feedback when shooting arrows in AC. Controller lasts a long time between charges.Bad:Unexpectedly powers off while in rest mode and this has happened to me 5 or 6 times since I bought it (mid Feb). Potential to damage the PS5 innards. Gets hot. Small memory. You'll see in my pics I am using a 1TB Samsung SSD because the console itself barely covers half a T of games and in 2021 and beyond, games are taking more and more space as time goes on. Want to keep at least 10 games installed so you can freely choose which one to play that instant? You're gonna need an external SSD drive, and I say SSD because you want to get the most out of your PS5's speed. This drive cost about $150, also purchased from AmazonOverall, fantastic but a little disappointed with the power shut off bug but bugs will come and go and Sony is always working 24/7 to update the console. I expect this bug to go away.

I have a 5.1.2 Dolby Atmos surround sound system and I wanted to watch some films using the 4K Blu Ray disc drive on this device. However, it has trouble connecting and recognizing the Atmos sound system, so much so that I just decided it's not worth the trouble to attempt to tinker and fix it, and to use a different device instead. For the amount of experience that Sony has in this industry, I expect a seamless and easy connection to my Atmos sound system. The controller is a step up over the previous generation, however the feedback triggers are too strong and make my hand cramp up while playing games that require their use a lot, such as FPS games. The design of the console itself is not aesthetically pleasing with a minimalist setup with a dark rosewood entertainment cabinet, so I keep it on the bottom shelf so it doesn't clash. It would have been better if it came in black instead of white.

After months of trying to land a PS5 on various sights, I was successful on Amazon. Having been a PlayStation owner since the PS1 and owning every generation, Sony held true to their reputation of innovation. The PS2 incorporated a DVD player into the console, eliminating the need for both on that TV. The PS3 brought support for both HDMI 1080p as well as incorporating a Bluray player at half the cost of stand-alone players at the time. The PS3's  MOVE system eventually evolved into PSVR for the PS4 and a better camera system.Sony has offered a free USB adapter to use the PS4 camera in order to continue to utilize the PSVR as the HD Camera is not compatible. But Be WARNED, the website mechanism to get your free adapter is highly broken. It took random attempts multiple times a day, for a couple weeks to finally get the form submission going through. I dont think I will ever forget the serial number on my VR controller module.The one negative thing I can say about the PS5 is that it really is meant to be mounted in the vertical position. Unfortunately I utilize some wall mounted glass media shelves and their proximity to the big screen wall mounted TV is too close for vertical without obscuring the screen. In vertical mode the support base has a screw that screws right into the base to increase the sturdy aspect. However in horizontal mode it just sort of rests on the base with two pieces of plastic semi-hugging the back edge of the unit. If you bump it or move it, it slides right off the base. The ps5, so many people are unable to acquire. I myself tried to get one at 30 or so drops. And I never thought I would get one from Amazon. But one night of being up at 1:00 a.m. later, I have one. This console is a great improvement over the PS4 platform. The PS4 that I own is a first-generation, the destiny limited edition one. And this console blows it out of the water, the graphics, the speed and the overall polish to the console, four months after launch, are overall fantastic. I will say it is quite large but I'd rather have quite large and good cooling than small and overheating. It's also super quiet the fan only kicks in every once in awhile It's not very loud. But the biggest showstopper is the controller, the haptic feedback on these controllers makes it feel like you could feel raindrops on any portion of it, the adaptive triggers can make it feel so stiff it feels you're going to break it. Every person I have brought over to my apartment to play it, even if they're not PlayStation fans say the controller might be enough to turn them over and have them buy one. And as someone who has always been a PlayStation gamer, and I slowly transition to a PC gamer I can't say I regret the decision to buy one. Is it overall fantastic addition to my collection of PlayStation. And I can't wait to continue playing destiny 2 on it. I will update this in the future if any adverse things start happening, but until then fantastic console if you can find one (non-scalper) and I would highly recommend it.

To start this review off, I have had my PlayStation 5 since early January and sadly there's not many PlayStation 5 games that are interesting to me with the exception of Demons Souls and I of course bought that.  When I first got it, it personally took me some time to get used to the new menu layout as compared to the PlayStation 4  and thankfully my unit doesn't make too much noise , but if it does, I hardly notice it nor care for it because I'm having a good time with my console when I enjoy some Demon Souls or a video game.  Speaking of which I mostly have been playing quite a bit of my PlayStation 4 library due to the lack of PlayStation 5 titles available that interest me.  The performance on them is quite good and in some cases the games run at a more stable frame rate and  in others I notice some compatibility  issues with certain titles or notice some graphics glitches on some but honestly you aren't missing out on a lot by not having your PlayStation 5, due  to the fact that there's not too many PlayStation 5 titles out as of this review .  Now for the subject of the controllers,  I still personally prefer the PlayStation 4 controller over the PlayStation 5 because it took a while for my hands to get used to the new controller,  the controller was awkward for me but it grew on me, I thought about getting aftermarket accessories to make it more comfortable to wield.  Then there was the new awkwardness of dealing with the built in controller mic, if you're the type of person that streams and you don't want your voice to be heard while doing so, make sure to mute the mic on your controller, so that way when it's uploaded to somewhere you won't have embarrassing moments being heard on your stream  or some sounds you make when dealing with a hard video game :]  Finally, let's talk about the party chat system, it's a lot more better in my opinion because when I was on my PlayStation 4 Pro, or regular PlayStation 4 when I had one, I would sometimes get a party chat invite, and when I wanted to join it, I would hit the PSN logo and join it, but in most cases it would cause my game to freeze very badly and in some cases crash my game when on PlayStation 4, but now when I get an invite and join a party, I don't have to deal with freezes or crashes anymore since it's more streamlined.  In a nutshell this console is great so far but it just doesn't have too many PlayStation 5 titles at the moment, so don't feel bad if you don't have one yet, personally I think Sony rushed this console out too soon .

One day luck was on my side and I was able to order one through Walmart just before Christmas. So I had this system for a while now. By far, it blows the new gen version of Xbox away. Newer games look simply amazing on PS5. I haven't had any weird hick-ups with Spiderman or COD CW. Warzone is my main game of choice right now and they keep adding HD texture updates that make the game look more and more amazing then on any other system (except maybe PC if you have a nice rig). Playing older PS4 games is nice as well. No real HD upgrades to the graphics here but much much shorter load time and even without graphical updates, most PS4 games just look better on my PS5. I havent played it much but CyberPunk was so much better and just look much more amazing on the PS5 then any other system and I played it on the Xbox One, Xbox Series, PS4, PC (not a great one though), and now PS5. Also the PS Plus upgrade for PS5 is great. It now comes with PS4 classics which includes some amazingly good games and the monthly games are A+ if you ask me. FFVII was just released yesterday and its barely 1 year old. Sound is good - amazing if you pair it with the Sony Pulse 3D headset. Many more kills in Warzone just because I can easily hear other players and know exactly where they are. Appearance-wise, biggest system I ever owned. I def did not like the look in pics but in-person it actually looks pretty cool. Its solid and almost feels like an expensive PC tower (not as big though). It feels heavy duty. Over the past few months I have been moving around a lot and taking this with me, not a scratch on it. Its been doing great. Only negative I can think of is the amount of current PS5 games out. Originally it was barely any. Seems like they are adding more regularly and PS4 games are getting nice upgrades. Anyway overall, great system. I wouldn't say the Xbox Series system even comes close to this. Moving from the Xbox to PS5 is almost like moving to a newer gen system... but the Xbox Series is a next gen system....Anyway, hard to get a PS5 but so worth the effort when you do.

Review: I'd like to start of by saying that I'm in love with my console, I only chose to give it 4 stars though because this thing is MASSIVE. It's both taller and nearly as wide as the original PS3 which was unit in and of itself. The PS5 console is great besides that and the build is quite nice. The Dualsense controller is absolutely perfect but I recommend turning off the adaptive trigger feature to prolong your controller's life; both from the physical and battery side of things.The console runs cool and isn't exactly whisper quiet as has been said but it isn't the jet engine that the previous PS4 was. The black strip that runs down the middle of the console is prone to both fingerprints and scratches so please be cautious.

Amazing system, super awesome performance, and an amazing controller. I‚Äôve had the console for about 2 months now, and it‚Äôs my favorite PlayStation yet! I‚Äôll get my complaints out of the way first:Limited SSD storage -667 gb usable means get an external to install your games!Archaic UI- So many settings are buried in weird menus, and even though I‚Äôm used to the switch of long press on the ps button, the quick switcher takes too many steps. Turning off the console, adjusting volume, creating a party are buried beneath so many taps and sub menus it‚Äôs infuriating.Limited IO- The ssd expansion is still locked for now, expected support is summer 2021PROS:Controller- even if the game doesn‚Äôt take advantage the vibration and feel of the new controller is awesome! Mic is passable but is helpful for quick chats. Make sure to turn on mute on login!Performance- games run great. On ps4 games the performance boosts in load times and frame rates are noticeable! A lot of games do have patches by now but very few are capped at 30. However, it is extra work for developers.Thermals- except for the disc spinning every now and then, the console is almost silent during even heavy gaming!Overall, I love this console and while the design is not my favorite, the performance and games alone are worth it!

I'm glad I was able to finally purchase this console after MONTHS of trying, but wow, is this miles ahead of the PS4. Although it's larger and doesn't really fit where I used to keep my PS4, this console is an absolute beauty, and outperforms my expectations.The Console itself:Having the disk is nice for older games, and in general I just like having the physical copies of the games laying around, but that's just me. Overall, I enjoy the design, even if I would've preferred the console to be black. It's performance is stellar on all games. Nothing much more to say other than: all the other reviews you've seen are right--the PS5 is amazing.The Controller:I thought that I should comment on the controller since it was a fairly large change that they made from the DUALSHOCK controllers of last generation. I enjoy the larger size, the texture is great--it has a good balance between grippyness and slipperiness that is much appreciated during gaming sessions. Additionally, its design is much more ergonomic than the DUALSHOCK ones, so after playing for a while, my hands were still feeling comfortable and not strained. One of the coolest things though, was the better rumble that they added, as it creates a much more immersive environment. That, mixed with the new triggers that they added, makes single player games much more enjoyable.TLDR; Worth the wait, lives up to the hype. Amazing!

I love this! The DualSense doesn't feel like a normal controller and the games speed of download and online play are insane fast! Can't wait to see what more games and features to come!Update: 12/6/2021 In depth:I will sum up of not just the physical look but performance and play overall on M.2 SSD and PS5 SSD etcThe PS5 may look, depending on people preference, special in its own way but the futuristic look of the console is a breath opener for whats to come when powered on making a great, eye catching, for what awaitsThe Look: Personally, I love the look. Not only because its something new, but looks nex gen and more out of the current gen style. I seen lots of memes of being a heater, LOL funny, but the look works and better prepare on how different this console is from any other PS System ever played on before. The system shells even have mini carved printed Triangle, Square, Cross, and Circle symbol from the playstation controller as unique feel on the case as well. The stand, no matter side ways or standing, RECOMMEND using it as the stand helps support the weight, especially on Digital owners as the digital version weight is top heavy. However, I don't like their isnt many USB slots on the PS5 as, depending if using VR too with the PULSE Headset, can take all slots easily.Gameplay: The games gameplay appeal, even in remakes of PS3/PS4 titles take things to a whole new level as the new software of PS and the Hardware specs are almost that of a PC spec of a RTX GPU with separate options. The promo of Ray Tracing is gorgeous to look at, the colors, HDR, saturation and even real time render of the reflections, shadows, and in game particles make game lookes like a real live movie or in real life time itself. The separate options are Fidelty (which keeps ray tracing and real shadows and particles but in 4K to full quailty but in 30FPS) or Performance (Which doesnt have Ray tracing but in full 60fps and runs smoother than previous console of PS4, even on PS4 games looks much smooth with update of PS5 patches) on both PS5 games and even in the PS5 settings for anyone looking for a separate Ray tracing or true 60fps experiance. With or Without any Ray Tracing or HDR, games still look amazing no matter what screen size from a 1080p or 4K even in upcoming 8K (which have been tested and looks great on OLED UHD TVs.Memory: The PS5 Speed of its internal SSD is amazing for reducing loading times and almost instant to a dime, its even faster, depending on your M.2 SSD, Speed making its almost none existence thas even on PS4 games. For Digital Owners, I recommend save for M.2 thats up to 2TB to 4TB as some PS5 games are large but worth it with expanded SSD. The PS5 Internal 825GB is ok, but not enough, especially if recording video on PS5 or even trophy achievement videos. Thankfully, can disable the trophy achieve videos to only image. The recommend M.2 SSD is Gen4 6000m/s speed and M.2 Thermal casing for a good reason. Yes, you can do with lower speeds at some M.2 but I wouldnt recommend that. You can use HDD but only for PS4 games as PS5 games need SSDs for speed and size of game that runs on them than a SATA HDD.Fan/Cooling: Thankfully, this is the same issue as with PS4/PS4 Pro as the fan is silent no matter the settings and hard push for game quality. The fan is cool and quiet and even testing temperature doesn't get anywhere near hot as long in a open desk or spaced area.The Controller: The DualSense... is MORE than just a controller. The haptic feedback works too well to even call as vibration. The triggers weight for the feedback and feature of the controllers motion ALL shine in Astro's Playroom Demo on the PS5 and recommend for ANY PS fan as it is token for not just being a demo to showcase the controllers features, but secret messages and easter eggs too. Besides the haptic feed, the Touch Pad has had even a small upgrade as feel on it tracks and feel the feed through press or sliding on the touch pad on the DualSense, at least in games like Astro's Playroom and Demon Souls, whether through the character you are playing or even the environment for the feed back of the wind or the quake of the ground or weapons and abilities from the trigger buttons. I do hope more game developers fully use the DualSense features to their protentional.Backwards Compatibility: as of 12/6/2021, PS5 is completely backwards compatible with 99.9% of PS4 games, PSVR games as well, and works with PS5 DualSense controllers, but I recommend PS4 DualShock 4 Controller on some games though. PS Plan for more different service for a answer for more games from previous generation but we will have to wait, if I test out, will update the review here.Pros:-Can play MANY PS4 games, Disk or Digital out the box via your PSN Account-Great library, so far and the planned games ahead-DualSense is a GREAT next generation of gaming introduction into next gen of gaming in general-Fast loading and expansive storage for PS5 M.2 SSDs-PS5 can use HDD for PS4 games but still increase loading on most games that been updated through the patch (although not as fast than on PS5 or M.2 SSD)Cons:-Hard to get one if any because scalper bots-Is big and can take up lots of space depending on desk size-Not many USB slots on the console-Removing the cover shell of PS5, if impatient, can scratch the console a bit (but isnt damaging)

It's a really awesome game console. I actually really like the new UI, and the controller is a major step forward. If it's taken you a while to get one though, it won't be anything major you're missing out on. Games run a bit better, and load times are much shorter. It's a great console, and I'm looking forward to seeing how it develops as more titles come out for it!

Got from the 02/16/2021 Amazon restock by using the ‚ÄúHotStock‚Äù app.Honestly, I‚Äôm having mixed feelings on this console so far. It‚Äôs quiet, it‚Äôs fast and the controller really wowed me with the built in mic and the haptic feedback. The 20 titles in the ‚ÄúPS Collection‚Äù that came for free with the PSplus membership is really nice, especially for those like me who traded in the majority of their PS4 things. Unfortunately, the graphics so far haven‚Äôt impressed me too much. Playing on the same 4K 60hz tv my PS4 slim was on and I really cannot tell the difference. Maybe getting a new display and hitting 120fps would make a noticeable difference, but I‚Äôm not going to spend the money to find out any time soon. The 650ish GBs worth of usable space on the SSD quickly vanished after installing 4 Ps5 titles and the PS4 copy of CyberPunk. Had to delete a few demos to make room. I understand Sony plans on offering more storage options in the future, but as of right now space is already an issue with only 5 disc games. This console is also HUGE. It makes my Xbox series S look like a model toy. The design of the console also isn‚Äôt very visually appealing. I‚Äôm sure some hotshot engineer/designer had some reasons for making it curvy and giving it a popped collar look at the top, but I feel like it isn‚Äôt necessary and could‚Äôve easily been made smaller without sacrificing airflow or heat dissipation. I travel for work, and getting this thing in my carry on luggage safely is going to be a challenge. The game lineup (Ps5 only exclusives) right now isn‚Äôt too great, although I‚Äôm sure that‚Äôll change closer to the end of 2021. After putting in all this effort to get my hands on one since preorders were announced, I honestly feel like it‚Äôs all just been hyped up thanks to scarce stock. For those still trying to get their hands on one, I don‚Äôt see the big rush in trying to upgrade until more games are released and Sony makes memory expansion for PS5 titles available. As of right now, it‚Äôs a PS4 pro with a fancy controller üôÉ

I‚Äôm just going to review the system and not the nightmare ordering process. I was lucky enough to get a pre-order in at another retailer.Like everyone says: It‚Äôs big. I‚Äôm including a photo of it next to a PS4 Pro. It‚Äôs almost too big for my entertainment console and it makes me a little nervous being so crammed in there, but it hasn‚Äôt overheated.The system can be loud at times. I didn‚Äôt expect that. The disc drive can also be loud at times. I would think by 2020, we‚Äôd have pretty quiet disc drives, but apparently not. Luckily it‚Äôs usually just in short bursts.I‚Äôve had no hardware issues at all with it. WiFi speed is much improved over the PS4, but I also don‚Äôt use the PS for app steaming. I have another device for that.As for the software, that‚Äôs why I am taking off a star. The OS is just too busy. It‚Äôs filled with a bunch of junk I don‚Äôt care about. The PS4 OS was very basic and largely unchanged from PS3, yes; however, I like simplicity. I wish in future updates it was simplified and cleaned up a little. I don‚Äôt want to see links to game news or videos on my home screen.Game-wise, there aren‚Äôt too many games right now that are worth playing. So if you still can‚Äôt get one (and please don‚Äôt pay/reward a scalper), you aren‚Äôt missing a lot. AC Valhalla looks like it could be on PS4. Miles Morales really shows off the almost-zero loading times, but could still be a PS4 game as the original Spider Man was already a visually amazing. You‚Äôre not missing out on anything cutting edge at this point.Long story short: Yeah, the roll out was awful. The system is holding up after 4 months so far. It can be a bit noisy. The OS could be cleaned up and simplified some. The really good games are still to come, so don‚Äôt fret if you can‚Äôt yet get one.

Finally got my PS5!  Everything I imagined and more.  Going from a basic PS4 to this has been a dream.  Playing Cyberpunk and Star Wars Jedi Fallen Order with a stable 60fps is beyond awesome.  MK 11 plus the other 2 games I mentioned load so incredibly fast.My Pros:- The best controller I've ever held in my hands.  Guys/Gals with big hands will fall in love with this controller.- The battery life feels like it last forever.  Nice to have your controller running for hours without having to worry about a charge.- Menu is easy to navigate and I love the UI.  Just sucks there arent any themes yet.  Hope they get added down the line!- Was very happy and pleasantly surprised when I could hook up the stand for my SkullCandy PLYR 1 headset and they worked like a charm and still sounded great.  Made sure to turn off 3D audio because that headset doesnt have that feature.- This system is beautiful.  Some people hate it but I fell in love with the design.Cons:Really, my only complaint is that this system is huge lol and I didnt fully understand when people said this until I got mine.  Definitely a big boy.  Not really a negative for me but if I had to complain about something that's it.Extra info:Was delivered in pristine condition.  No dents or dings even on the outside box.  Also I heard that some had issues with the sleep mode.  I've had none.  Not saying it doesnt exsist but personally I have had no problems with it.  However i have heard about people with external hard drives that have an issue with putting your PS5 in sleep mode with the external hard drive attached.  Dont have any info on that but I would look up info on the subject just to be on the safe side of things.  Havent tested the haptic feedback yet, so I cant give my thought on that yet.I'm completely satisfied with this purchase and it went beyond my expectations.
Not a gamer but I am having fun gaming on this thing. Get one if and when you can.

Had this console for a little over 2 weeks and it‚Äôs a great console. Comparing to the PS4 Pro it‚Äôs miles faster, cooler and quieter. Sony didn‚Äôt cut corners with this console in any way and it runs perfectly fine. Although this console has good things it also has some negative things. In order to use this console to its max you need a 4k, HDR10, and 120Hz tv/monitor. It is useless when if you are considering to play anything less than that. Currently I‚Äôm on HDR, 4K, but 60Hz and In games like Cold War (PS5 Version), the frames tend to drop when the game is at its stressful moments. RTX and other graphical improvements aren‚Äôt groundbreaking because it‚Äôs a cod game but it‚Äôs definitely noticeable on other games like Spider-Man: Miles Morales. I was running it at 60FPS in its highest setting and never seemed to go below 55. Lastly if you are moving from a base PS4 or Base Xbox it‚Äôs a night and day difference going from 720p-1080p all the way to 4K 120Hz gameplay. If you had a Xbox One X or a PS4 pro you won‚Äôt see many differences in terms of graphical advances but that isn‚Äôt a bad thing. I haven‚Äôt ran into any issues yet with this console so i can‚Äôt speak how good it is long term. Finally the console is huge. Way bigger than the base Xbox One and I can barely fit it at the spot I have it in. Not sure why Sony thought to make such a bug machine since the Series X is more powerful yet smaller. It is beautiful though not going to lie. Great Console!

Why Should you buy a PS5?If you don't have a PC, this is a must buy and delivers the best price for graphics.If you have a PC, buy a PS5 for the amazing exclusives that Sony will surely deliver, and to play the older gen titles such as GoW, HZD, Bloodbourne etc etc in 4k 60fps. Additionally the controller's dual sense technology is simply amazing and something that has HUGE potential if utilized properly.What are some things you will love about the PS5?Extremely easy to transfer your PS4 games to PS5. You can directly connect PS4 external storage and the games will work. You can also connect both PS4 and PS5 over WiFi+Ethernet cable and have all the games transferred within the hour.Download speeds are much much much better.Huge difference in the responsive of the controller. It just works better than the DS4 on PS4 games.The haptic feedback and triggers are absolutely absolutely crazy. A lot has already been said but some examples are: The controller will provide feedback so it will feel like you are in water when walking in water, when are walking on a glass surface or on a metal surface etc etc.Another example is in Astrobot, when you are "carrying" many bouncy balls and you could feel the bouncy balls rolling inside the controller.There is just no way to explain it in words. You have to experience it.The controller's built in mic is REALLY good and has excellent noise cancellation.PS Plus Collection is a great add on to get started and gives you around 20 "old-gen" games FOR FREE.What are some things you wont like about the PS5?The size.Very few "next-gen" games available at launch.The UI and menu while its pretty fast and responsive lacks features. Powering down, changing sound output, finding games requires several button presses and can feel like a hassle compared to PS4's "quick menu".

The delay of the PlayStation 5 in the retail market is not unusual. Demand is created before the product is available for release. The covid issue has exasperated the production delay. Not really much left to say about this system. It is extremely tough to find now. I got lucky with preorders back in September. The system arrived launch day in November. Here's a quick list of pros and cons:Pros:-the dual sense is the real deal. It's a huge new immersion level to gaming.-the games load rapidly on the SSD.-some games take advantage of next gen technology like ray tracing.-HDR looks amazing on this device and seamlessly works between games and UI.-Playstation store downloads are fast. Can download and install large games within an hour.-dolby digital surround sound is amazing with the right hardware.Cons:-of course the biggest is the system is impossible to find now. This is a factor of COVID supply chain issued, inability to purchase in store, and holiday rush madness.-no support for dolby atmos.-the system itself is massive. Although I personally like the design a lot.-the hard drive all things considered is too small. It will need an expansion soon.-many games now are 70 dollars.

The PS5 is a good system, not great. I own both this and the Series X and I can say that overall the SX is superior as far as interface speed, slightly faster loading times and better graphics on almost all backwards compatibility games. They don't look bad on PS5, games like AC Origins, Odyssey, Crash 4 etc. And they have a nice clarity to them. But they really lack certain textures and the color gamut is very pale in comparison. imo. Now when you're talking exclusives (from PS4) PS5 is the way to go, all the PS4 titles look amazing as they did on PS4/Pro. I think most of these games have received special "treatment" other 3rd party titles have not. And Sony just have the worlds best exclusives bar none.  But until actual titles made just for the PS5 are released, and not for the PS4/Pro. I can't recommend it. Because once you play these games you sit and go, well, now what? So I'd recommend holding onto your pro, since these are scarce anyway, and just wait. The same can be said for the Xbox Series X, but then again games pass just kills it, tons of free games, and if you're more of a 3rd party title person. it's just a no brainer. So the hype isn't that real about the PS5, it is a "good" system, but I think in the future it will be great!! Also all the problems people say they've had or are having with this, I'm not experiencing any. Super quiet, cool and not a single glitch.

Sony, you suck.

Okay, I, like so many who have written on this site, tried desperately to get a PS5 on pre-order in September but it didn‚Äôt happen. I was on Amazon, Sony, and the list goes on but the bots got them and anyone who has been on eBay knows what I‚Äôm talking about. I did however, put in an order for a PS5 through an ‚ÄúAvailable from these sellers‚Äù link on Amazon on November 12th but when I got to the links I was shocked at the pricing, the sellers were on eBay, StockX all over the place and prices were out of this world. Disc units were going for up to $2000 USD, and digital the same. I ended up hooked up with a seller however, through Amazon, even after Amazon killed the link. You can still buy ALL of the accessories for the PS5 on Amazon from, ‚ÄúAvailable from these sellers‚Äù from the three D headphones to remotes cameras etc. and they are ALL brokers but not PS5‚Äôs. So, when I learned that the units are hopelessly out of stock and most likely won‚Äôt be in stock until next May or June, I bit the bullet and bought an all-digital unit for $999.First impressions, if Sony was looking to release a twenty-first century looking unit, they missed the mark by sixty-five years. If this unit were released at Disney Land in tomorrow land in 1955 it would have worked but in 2020 NOPE. My wife looked at it when I put it on the TV stand on its side as that‚Äôs how I use my units and she said, ‚ÄúIt looks smushed, did someone sit on it or did it melt?‚Äù I could not help myself I just started laughing because the unit itself is UGLY.Size and shell construction, the unit weighs fourteen pounds, and is double the size of the PS4 it is incredibly quiet when running but it‚Äôs massive and takes up a lot of space. The shell looks terrible the white shell is very, very thin plastic if you drop this you WILL break it, the inner black is shiny but Sony would have been better off going all black. I understand they need to cool the components but aesthetically the unit is ugly.On the front of the unit there is a standard USB 2.0 and a high-speed USB 3.0. On the back you have power, the HDMI out for video and audio to the TV and ethernet hub (I don‚Äôt know why Sony did this everything is wireless these days) then two USB 2.0 high speed hubs there is NO optical input/output on the PS5 for headphones and PS5 does NOT support Bluetooth audio yet again.The unit is supposed to come with an internal one TB SSD drive that‚Äôs not what you get, its actually about 690 GHZ and if you download your PS4 games to it you will eat up the drive in a flash, no pun intended. So, you need an external drive, however, here is where the money starts adding up. The unit itself is cheap but all you get is the system and one controller and if you‚Äôre a gamer like me, you need more than one controller and a lot more stuff, and that runs up the tab so you better have a lot of cash to invest in this system.Sony says you can use your HDD from your PS4 on the PS5 to play your PS4 games NOT SO, the PS5 does NOT read the HDD so forget about it I tried every work around I could (I was on YouTube for hours looking and nothing) the system would not recognize any of my HDD drives. So, I invested in a Samsung 1 TB SSD drive $200 bucks you‚Äôre going to need this and you‚Äôre going to need an even bigger drive. I have looked at other SSD drives and for a five TB SSD it is about $600 so get ready to put out a lot more cash for this system. Given the sheer size of games coming to the console in the coming months and years one TB might hold only one or two games.Speed: Load speeds are okay, when I load GTA Online with my high-speed internet it takes about forty seconds. Now that is fast when you consider on PS4 it takes about a minute to a minute and a half or longer as Rockstar advertises in game stuff during the load. I‚Äôm sure that Rockstar and Take Two Interactive will find a way to slow the process when they release the new GTA Online later next year. In game frame rate changes, fast and clean however, the system moves a little too fast for a lot of PS4 games like Hitman, Assassins Creed Call of Duty and the list goes one so the images can get blurry. I thought it was my vision at first but it‚Äôs not, the PS5 moves so fast the games can‚Äôt load as fast as the processor in the PS5 can bus the data.Picture: I went all out before buying the PS5 and invested in a brand new 2020 75‚Äù Samsung QLED 800 Smart Ultra 8K TV. The TV converts anything to HD and to 4K and it has a game mode setting on it to improve the look of games so I really see little difference between my games from PS4 to PS5. However, if you don‚Äôt have at least a 4K TV you‚Äôre wasting your money on this system, the PS5 is designed for 4K and can be upgraded (at an extra cost) to 8K which I did by purchasing high speed 8K HDMI cables $90. So, beware if you‚Äôre going to go in on this system you better be prepared to put out at least another one to two thousand dollars if you go low end with the TV and accessories, if you go high end like I did, well, let‚Äôs just say I‚Äôm in now about $5K. However, while the in-game picture and graphics are GREAT if you want to watch a movie or video the quality of the images goes down hill fast. The system darkens the video and I have done every possible fix I can on the PS5 and nothing works. However, if I go over to my PS4 the picture is GREAT so it definitely has something to do with the PS5 video cards but I have no idea what it is I hope Sony will release a patch for this but as of now I can‚Äôt stream movies or TV shows on PS5, at and at least not enjoy them.Audio: Sony has been touting their custom 3D audio and they have released a new pair of headphones just for this new audio. A word of warning, this audio ONLY works with select games, as of right now the only game I have that it works with is Assassins Creed Valhalla, if you use the 3D audio settings for other games the sound sucks plain and simple. The Sony headphones are going to set you back another $100 so be prepared for that. All in all, on the audio I‚Äôm not impressed at ALL either on my TV or my headphones. I use regular settings on my phones and the sounds is as good as on my PS4 so to me the 3D build is hype perhaps some reading this can tell me if they have found a way to use the 3D audio successfully.Overall impression of the PS5? Not impressed, for a next gen console and all the hype that Sony has put out on this it really is no big deal. In the end when the units are plentiful and everyone can get their hands on one Sony is going to make bank not on the systems but the accessories, I know there are bugs still to work out but a month and a half in I wish I would have saved my money and waited until spring.

I have every Nintendo and every Playstation and have them all hooked up and ready to play anytime I want.  The PS5 is definitely not worth the hype.  The graphics and speed are only incrementally better than the PS4 and on top of that the UI is laggy and is about the same speed as well. The build quality is for crap as well.  I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs me, but the system still gets very hot and is as loud as the PS4 was, if not more.  I don‚Äôt know what they were talking about with the haptic feedback being better.  I did not notice any difference between the PS4 and this.  Since I have both systems hooked up I turned both on and was switching back and forth and did not notice and discernable difference on any of the items I just went into.  So, I‚Äôm not sure what Sony was talking about when they said it was a huge improvement.  They definitely hyped this system up way too much and it does not live up to it.  This is the biggest disappointment since I got Gran Turismo Sport.  When I got that I put it in the system once and realized what it was.  So, I took it out and put it up on the shelf and there it has sat since the game has come out.  I will more than likely being doing the same thing with this thing.  If you must have it, I would wait a couple years for them to at least fix all the technical issues.  But, by that time the PS5 Pro will be out and then you would have to wait a couple more years for the bugs to be worked out on that as well and then by that time it would be better to just wait until the PS6 comes out.  Honestly this is not a good generation for gaming consoles as whole, especially the PS5.  So, if I were you I would wait until the PS6.  Hopefully they get their act together by then, otherwise I feel as if game consoles won‚Äôt last.  I will say it again, this is the biggest let down since Gran Turismo Sport.

Excellent loading time of games and apps. Only about 5 games available for it so far. Graphics are not all that better than my original PS4, even with a TV that does 60fps and HDR. The menu isn't as convenient as the PS4's. The white color really sticks out in the room, which may be good or bad depending on your preference. A lot about the PS5 seems rushed in development to me. The Astrobot game it comes with however is a really nice game with impressive graphics and controls showing off the new controller, better than most of the games you can buy for it on release, so that was  really nice surprise.

Very happy i managed to preorder one back in September and get it on launch day. My PS5 has been running perfectly so far. The new controller is the best Sony has ever produced, the new rumble features are cool...but it's the adaptive triggers i think will impress me more in the future. (if developers actually implement it)The system itself is VERY large and unfortunately needs the stand to even lay down horizontally because of it's weird shape. I really can't wait for the PS5 Slim that should be out in a few years. While it's a matter of opinion, the PS5 is overall an aesthetically ugly console, it's large and overally designed in my view. But i am overall bias towards simple designs. BUT, regardless of looks...it's a solid gaming system and i'm hyped for all those future exclusives!*TO THE PEOPLE COMPLAINING ABOUT STOCK*:To the people complaining about stock....honestly... just be patient. Eventually stock will be replenished and there will come a time when you'll be able to just walk into a GameStop or Bestbuy and get a PS5. (within the next few months most likely). Don't give scalpers your money over the hype of the system and the holidays, go get a Switch Lite and a bunch of games or something and ride it out. Distract yourself until availability returns to normal. ALSO, as someone with a PS5...there isn't really much to play on it at the moment either way (I'm mostly playing older PS4 games on it at the moment). And all the real big titles aren't out until 2021 and beyond anyways. So it's actually more lucrative to wait it out. The time will come, just like every other console that was hard to find at launch were they'll be commonly found everywhere in due time.Don't stress out over a gaming machine or pay double or more for a system that will most likely become available within a few months next year.
